introduction.p: We must exclude from the domain of a function any values of the input that would cause us to divide by zero or to take the square root of a negative number. To find these values, we usually solve an equation.
We may also solve an equation to find the domain value for a given range value.

solution.p: We isolate x by "undoing" each operation in order: perform the opposite operations. \begin{aligned}[t] 3\sqrt{x-4} \amp = 15 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by 3.}}\\ \sqrt{x-4} \amp = 5 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Square both sides.}}\\ x-4 \amp = 25 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Add 4 to both sides.}}\\ x \amp = 29 \end{aligned} Whenever we square both sides of an equation, we should check for extraneous solutions. 3\sqrt{\alert{29}-4} = 3\sqrt{25} = 3(5)=15 Because setting x=29 does not cause us to take the square root of a negative number, the solution is 29.

statement.p: Let ~f(x)=\dfrac{24}{x-1}. Find a so that f(a) = 4.

solution.p: We must solve the equation \dfrac{24}{a-1} = 4 First, we clear the fraction by multiplying both sides by (a-1). \begin{aligned}[t] \dfrac{24}{a-1} \blert{(a-1)} \amp = 4 \blert{(a-1)} \amp\amp \blert{\text{Multiply by}~(a-1).}\\ 24 \amp = 4(a-1) \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by 4.}}\\ 6 \amp = a-1 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Add 1 to both sides.}}\\ 7 \amp = a \end{aligned} Substituting 7 into a-1, we see that 7 does not cause the denominator to be 0, so 7 is the solution, and f(7)=4.

introduction.p: Recall that the equation for a circle of radius r centered at the origin is x^2+y^2=r^2

ol.label: a
ol.li: Solve the equation ~x^2+y^2=9~ for y to get two functions.
Find two points on the circle that have x-coordinate 1.

li.p: \begin{aligned}[t] x^2+y^2 \amp = 9 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Subtract}~x^2~\text{from both sides.}}\\ y^2 \amp = 9 - x^2 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Take square roots.}}\\ y \amp = \pm \sqrt{9-x^2} \end{aligned} The two functions are ~y = \sqrt{9-x^2}~ and ~y = -\sqrt{9-x^2}~.
